title: Iron bars
data:

| ---------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------- |

| [# Corridor](/wiki/Corridor "Corridor")                          | [# Cloud](/wiki/Cloud "Cloud")              |
| [#. Drawbridge](/wiki/Drawbridge "Drawbridge")                   | [+-\| Door](/wiki/Door "Door")              |
| [. Doorway](/wiki/Doorway "Doorway")                             | [{ Fountain](/wiki/Fountain "Fountain")     |
| [\| Headstone](/wiki/Headstone "Headstone")                      | [.  Floor](/wiki/Floor "Floor")             |
| [>< Ladder](/wiki/Ladder "Ladder")                               | [. Ice](/wiki/Ice "Ice")                    |
| [# Iron bars]()                                                  | [} Lava](/wiki/Lava "Lava")                 |
| [} Moat](/wiki/Moat "Moat")                                      | [# Sink](/wiki/Sink "Sink")                 |
| [  Solid rock](/wiki/Solid_rock "Solid rock")                    | [>< Staircase](/wiki/Staircase "Staircase") |
| [\ Throne](/wiki/Throne "Throne")                                | [^" Trap](/wiki/Trap "Trap")                |

| [\~ Vibrating square](/wiki/Vibrating_square "Vibrating square") |                                             |

**Iron bars** are a [dungeon feature](/wiki/Dungeon_feature "Dungeon feature") that appear in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*, represented by #.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [5.2 SporkHack](#SporkHack)
  - [5.3 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [5.4 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [5.5 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

- [6 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly generated inaccessible [closets](/wiki/Closet "Closet") (that have a guaranteed [scroll of teleportation](/wiki/Scroll_of_teleportation "Scroll of teleportation")) have a 1⁄5 chance of iron bars being generated where the door would be.

Iron bars also appear in the following branches and special levels:

- The [Minetown](/wiki/Minetown "Minetown") variant [Orcish Town](/wiki/Minetown#Orcish_Town "Minetown") will also have several iron bars blocking off entrance into the ruined town.
- There are guaranteed iron bars in the [Wizard](/wiki/Wizard_quest "Wizard quest"), [Tourist](/wiki/Tourist_quest "Tourist quest"), and [Ranger quests](/wiki/Ranger_quest "Ranger quest").
- The [Big Room](/wiki/Big_Room "Big Room") has a wall of iron bars in the middle of the map for #8, and there is a chance of iron bars being selected as the terrain for maps #1 and #10.
- The fourth [snake](/wiki/Snake "Snake")-filled variant of [Medusa's Island](/wiki/Medusa%27s_Island "Medusa's Island") has some iron bars around [Medusa](/wiki/Medusa "Medusa")'s dwelling.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [commit 4af086be](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/4af086be73b8f11563ff8fa0af4c57c222227a93) and [commit 0bfd6b22](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/0bfd6b22f1d5e1ab6943079eab94053267bf7e6f), some Gehennom levels have iron bars instead of walls.

## Description

Iron bars cannot be [dug](/wiki/Digging "Digging") through, and objects thrown through them have a chance of being stopped by the iron bars. Specifically, large objects such as most melee [weapons](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon"), most [armor](/wiki/Armor "Armor") and [boulders](/wiki/Boulder "Boulder") will always be stopped - smaller objects such as [potions](/wiki/Potion "Potion") and most [projectiles](/wiki/Projectile "Projectile") (including [spears](/wiki/Spear "Spear"), but not [daggers](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger") or [boomerangs](/wiki/Boomerang "Boomerang")) will pass through with a 4⁄5 chance, and will always pass through if they are thrown from a square adjacent to the bars in question.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) [Rays](/wiki/Ray "Ray") (e.g. [dragon](/wiki/Dragon "Dragon") [breath](/wiki/Breath "Breath")) and [beams](/wiki/Beam "Beam") will always pass right through iron bars.

All monsters that are [whirly](/wiki/Whirly "Whirly"), [amorphous](/wiki/Amorphous "Amorphous"), [phasing](/wiki/Phasing "Phasing"), [tiny](/wiki/Tiny "Tiny"), or else medium-sized (or smaller) and [slithy](/wiki/Slithy "Slithy"), can pass through them, and monsters with rusting or corrosive attacks, such as [rust monsters](/wiki/Rust_monster "Rust monster") and [gray oozes](/wiki/Gray_ooze "Gray ooze"), can eat through the bars.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) Characters can do the same by [polymorphing](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into a monster with any of these properties. A bug identified in [NetHack 3.4.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.0 "NetHack 3.4.0") allows whirly and/or amorphous [engulfing](/wiki/Engulfing "Engulfing") monsters to pass through iron bars while engulfing a monster (e.g. the unpolymorphed character) that cannot.

[Acid](/wiki/Acid "Acid") can be used to dissolve iron bars: smashing a [wielded](/wiki/Wield "Wield") [potion of acid](/wiki/Potion_of_acid "Potion of acid") onto them using [F](/wiki/F "F") will dissolve them, while a thrown potion only has a 1⁄5 chance of hitting the bars due to the aforementioned.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](#cite_note-5) The acidic breath of a [yellow dragon](/wiki/Yellow_dragon "Yellow dragon") will dissolve the bars as well.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6) Bars that are marked "[non-diggable](/wiki/Non-diggable "Non-diggable")" cannot be dissolved by any of these methods.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

The bug that lets engulfers pull engulfed monsters through iron bars that they could not pass otherwise is fixed via [commit 21068b05](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/21068b05c5c98ad7d5e50a9dbaa1b6256063e2e3).

Per [commit f61e1e8e](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/f61e1e8e23f48f670c5b7c465089effd7743aba9), there is a small chance of breaking iron bars by hitting them with a [war hammer](/wiki/War_hammer "War hammer"). [commit c212ee44](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/c212ee44c06cb5ef5fec1a7f02d7c48c13f46fd6) extends this to include hitting them with a [heavy iron ball](/wiki/Heavy_iron_ball "Heavy iron ball"). The chance is dependent on the character's strength, whether they throw or force-fight with the weapon, and the weapon's enchantment or iron ball's weight.

Per [commit 738c2239](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/738c2239c9063cbf62e5650977da45c1e38a3108), there is a 1⁄10 chance that iron bars will melt when hit by [lightning](/wiki/Lightning "Lightning").

Per [commit 0e713dc4](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/0e713dc4e90eba08ec50c4260a36161d5f3db4d8), all metallivores are also capable of eating iron bars.

## Strategy

Iron bars do not impede visibility, allowing spellcasting or wand-using players and monsters to direct their beams, rays and gazes through them. In particular, this can be used to pick off Orcish Town's invaders without as much immediate risk to yourself - but beware of the [poisoned](/wiki/Poison "Poison") [arrows](/wiki/Arrow "Arrow") that many of them can fire back at you, especially if you lack [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance").

The iron bars on the fourth variant of Medusa's Island present a significant hazard: you may inadvertently catch a glimpse of Medusa through the bars as you approach her, depending on where she is first generated, and risk being immediately [petrified](/wiki/Petrified "Petrified"). Wearing a [blindfold](/wiki/Blindfold "Blindfold") or [towel](/wiki/Towel "Towel") well before approaching is a good idea, especially if you lack [reflection](/wiki/Reflection "Reflection").

## History

Iron bars first appear in [NetHack 3.1.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.0 "NetHack 3.1.0"), when the [Quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") was introduced to the game.

[NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0") introduces the more commonplace iron bars in the main dungeon, and is the first version where certain monsters can eat through them; [NetHack 3.6.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.1 "NetHack 3.6.1") adds the ability to dissolve iron bars with acid, imported from UnNetHack.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), iron bars can be found in some of the [Sokoban](/wiki/Sokoban_\(SLASH%27EM\) "Sokoban (SLASH'EM)") levels, and also appear in [Grund's Stronghold](/wiki/Grund%27s_Stronghold "Grund's Stronghold"). Some maze levels within the dungeon may be partially comprised of iron bars, e.g. in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom") - these can prove especially annoying during the [ascension run](/wiki/Ascension_run "Ascension run").

In addition to the applicable methods described above, player [dopplegangers](/wiki/Doppelganger_\(starting_race\) "Doppelganger (starting race)") can use the [liquid leap](/wiki/Liquid_leap "Liquid leap") [technique](/wiki/Technique "Technique") to pass through them. This can even be used on the iron bars in Sokoban, which otherwise prevents creatures from passing through them.

### SporkHack

In [SporkHack](/wiki/SporkHack "SporkHack"), iron bars are sometimes generated as part of room-and-corridor dungeon levels.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), iron bars appear in some of the [Sokoban](/wiki/Sokoban_\(UnNetHack\) "Sokoban (UnNetHack)") levels and Gehennom mazes as in SLASH'EM. They also appear much more frequently within the main dungeon, often replacing doorways and sections of rock wall within room-and-corridor levels - as mentioned above, UnNetHack is also the first variant that allows them to be dissolved via acid.

A ring of iron bars is created around the [magic portal](/wiki/Magic_portal "Magic portal") connecting the [Black Market](/wiki/Black_Market "Black Market") to the main dungeon if you attempt to steal anything from the shops.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), characters can break iron bars with a [wand of striking](/wiki/Wand_of_striking "Wand of striking"), [force bolt](/wiki/Force_bolt "Force bolt"), or a laser such as a [lightsaber](/wiki/Lightsaber "Lightsaber") - this will produce 1-7 [iron bar](/wiki/Iron_bar "Iron bar") objects. These bars can be picked up and wielded as weapons, and use the [quarterstaff](/wiki/Quarterstaff "Quarterstaff") skill.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), iron bars can also be broken with a force bolt or wand of striking.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/mthrowu.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 476](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mthrowu.c#L476): *calls `hits_bars`*
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/mthrowu.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1122](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mthrowu.c#L1122): *`hits_bars` function*
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/mondata.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 325](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mondata.c#L325): *`passes_bars` function*
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/hack.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1632](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/hack.c#L1632)
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [src/mthrowu.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1136](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mthrowu.c#L1136)
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [src/zap.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 4567](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/zap.c#L4567)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
html:
Iron bars

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
Dungeon features
  Air _ Altar
# Corridor # Cloud
#. Drawbridge +-| Door
. Doorway { Fountain
| Headstone .  Floor
>< Ladder . Ice
# Iron bars } Lava
} Moat # Sink
  Solid rock >< Staircase
\ Throne ^" Trap
# Tree - | Wall
~ Vibrating square

Iron bars are a dungeon feature that appear in NetHack, represented by #.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Description
  • 3 Strategy
  • 4 History
  • 5 Variants
    • 5.1 SLASH'EM
    • 5.2 SporkHack
    • 5.3 UnNetHack
    • 5.4 dNetHack
    • 5.5 EvilHack
  • 6 References

Generation

Randomly generated inaccessible closets (that have a guaranteed scroll of teleportation) have a 1⁄5 chance of iron bars being generated where the door would be.

Iron bars also appear in the following branches and special levels:

  • The Minetown variant Orcish Town will also have several iron bars blocking off entrance into the ruined town.
  • There are guaranteed iron bars in the Wizard, Tourist, and Ranger quests.
  • The Big Room has a wall of iron bars in the middle of the map for #8, and there is a chance of iron bars being selected as the terrain for maps #1 and #10.
  • The fourth snake-filled variant of Medusa's Island has some iron bars around Medusa's dwelling.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Per commit 4af086be and commit 0bfd6b22, some Gehennom levels have iron bars instead of walls.

Description

Iron bars cannot be dug through, and objects thrown through them have a chance of being stopped by the iron bars. Specifically, large objects such as most melee weapons, most armor and boulders will always be stopped - smaller objects such as potions and most projectiles (including spears, but not daggers or boomerangs) will pass through with a 4⁄5 chance, and will always pass through if they are thrown from a square adjacent to the bars in question.[1][2] Rays (e.g. dragon breath) and beams will always pass right through iron bars.

All monsters that are whirly, amorphous, phasing, tiny, or else medium-sized (or smaller) and slithy, can pass through them, and monsters with rusting or corrosive attacks, such as rust monsters and gray oozes, can eat through the bars.[3] Characters can do the same by polymorphing into a monster with any of these properties. A bug identified in NetHack 3.4.0 allows whirly and/or amorphous engulfing monsters to pass through iron bars while engulfing a monster (e.g. the unpolymorphed character) that cannot.

Acid can be used to dissolve iron bars: smashing a wielded potion of acid onto them using F will dissolve them, while a thrown potion only has a 1⁄5 chance of hitting the bars due to the aforementioned.[4][5] The acidic breath of a yellow dragon will dissolve the bars as well.[6] Bars that are marked "non-diggable" cannot be dissolved by any of these methods.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

The bug that lets engulfers pull engulfed monsters through iron bars that they could not pass otherwise is fixed via commit 21068b05.

Per commit f61e1e8e, there is a small chance of breaking iron bars by hitting them with a war hammer. commit c212ee44 extends this to include hitting them with a heavy iron ball. The chance is dependent on the character's strength, whether they throw or force-fight with the weapon, and the weapon's enchantment or iron ball's weight.

Per commit 738c2239, there is a 1⁄10 chance that iron bars will melt when hit by lightning.

Per commit 0e713dc4, all metallivores are also capable of eating iron bars.

Strategy

Iron bars do not impede visibility, allowing spellcasting or wand-using players and monsters to direct their beams, rays and gazes through them. In particular, this can be used to pick off Orcish Town's invaders without as much immediate risk to yourself - but beware of the poisoned arrows that many of them can fire back at you, especially if you lack poison resistance.

The iron bars on the fourth variant of Medusa's Island present a significant hazard: you may inadvertently catch a glimpse of Medusa through the bars as you approach her, depending on where she is first generated, and risk being immediately petrified. Wearing a blindfold or towel well before approaching is a good idea, especially if you lack reflection.

History

Iron bars first appear in NetHack 3.1.0, when the Quest was introduced to the game.

NetHack 3.6.0 introduces the more commonplace iron bars in the main dungeon, and is the first version where certain monsters can eat through them; NetHack 3.6.1 adds the ability to dissolve iron bars with acid, imported from UnNetHack.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, iron bars can be found in some of the Sokoban levels, and also appear in Grund's Stronghold. Some maze levels within the dungeon may be partially comprised of iron bars, e.g. in Gehennom - these can prove especially annoying during the ascension run.

In addition to the applicable methods described above, player dopplegangers can use the liquid leap technique to pass through them. This can even be used on the iron bars in Sokoban, which otherwise prevents creatures from passing through them.

SporkHack

In SporkHack, iron bars are sometimes generated as part of room-and-corridor dungeon levels.

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, iron bars appear in some of the Sokoban levels and Gehennom mazes as in SLASH'EM. They also appear much more frequently within the main dungeon, often replacing doorways and sections of rock wall within room-and-corridor levels - as mentioned above, UnNetHack is also the first variant that allows them to be dissolved via acid.

A ring of iron bars is created around the magic portal connecting the Black Market to the main dungeon if you attempt to steal anything from the shops.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, notdNetHack and notnotdNetHack, characters can break iron bars with a wand of striking, force bolt, or a laser such as a lightsaber - this will produce 1-7 iron bar objects. These bars can be picked up and wielded as weapons, and use the quarterstaff skill.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, iron bars can also be broken with a force bolt or wand of striking.

References

  1. ↑ src/mthrowu.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 476: calls hits_bars
  2. ↑ src/mthrowu.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1122: hits_bars function
  3. ↑ src/mondata.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 325: passes_bars function
  4. ↑ src/hack.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1632
  5. ↑ src/mthrowu.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1136
  6. ↑ src/zap.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 4567

rawPage: {{features}} '''Iron bars''' are a [[dungeon feature]] that appear in ''[[NetHack]]'', represented by {{cyan|#}}. ==Generation== Randomly generated inaccessible [[closet]]s (that have a guaranteed [[scroll of teleportation]]) have a {{frac|5}} chance of iron bars being generated where the door would be. Iron bars also appear in the following branches and special levels: * The [[Minetown]] variant [[Minetown#Orcish Town|Orcish Town]] will also have several iron bars blocking off entrance into the ruined town. * There are guaranteed iron bars in the [[Wizard quest|Wizard]], [[Tourist quest|Tourist]], and [[Ranger quest]]s. * The [[Big Room]] has a wall of iron bars in the middle of the map for #8, and there is a chance of iron bars being selected as the terrain for maps #1 and #10. * The fourth [[snake]]-filled variant of [[Medusa's Island]] has some iron bars around [[Medusa]]'s dwelling. {{upcoming|NetHack 3.7.0|Per {{commit|4af086be73b8f11563ff8fa0af4c57c222227a93}} and {{commit|0bfd6b22f1d5e1ab6943079eab94053267bf7e6f}}, some Gehennom levels have iron bars instead of walls.}} ==Description== Iron bars cannot be [[digging|dug]] through, and objects thrown through them have a chance of being stopped by the iron bars. Specifically, large objects such as most melee [[weapon]]s, most [[armor]] and [[boulder]]s will always be stopped - smaller objects such as [[potion]]s and most [[projectile]]s (including [[spear]]s, but not [[dagger]]s or [[boomerang]]s) will pass through with a {{frac|4|5}} chance, and will always pass through if they are thrown from a square adjacent to the bars in question.{{refsrc|src/mthrowu.c|476|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=calls hits_bars}}{{refsrc|src/mthrowu.c|1122|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=hits_bars function}} [[Ray]]s (e.g. [[dragon]] [[breath]]) and [[beam]]s will always pass right through iron bars. All monsters that are [[whirly]], [[amorphous]], [[phasing]], [[tiny]], or else medium-sized (or smaller) and [[slithy]], can pass through them, and monsters with rusting or corrosive attacks, such as [[rust monster]]s and [[gray ooze]]s, can eat through the bars.{{refsrc|src/mondata.c|325|version=NetHack 3.6.7|comment=passes_bars function}} Characters can do the same by [[polymorph]]ing into a monster with any of these properties. A bug identified in [[NetHack 3.4.0]] allows whirly and/or amorphous [[engulfing]] monsters to pass through iron bars while engulfing a monster (e.g. the unpolymorphed character) that cannot. [[Acid]] can be used to dissolve iron bars: smashing a [[wield]]ed [[potion of acid]] onto them using {{kbd|F}} will dissolve them, while a thrown potion only has a {{frac|5}} chance of hitting the bars due to the aforementioned.{{refsrc|src/hack.c|1632|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}{{refsrc|src/mthrowu.c|1136|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} The acidic breath of a [[yellow dragon]] will dissolve the bars as well.{{refsrc|src/zap.c|4567|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} Bars that are marked "[[non-diggable]]" cannot be dissolved by any of these methods. {{upcoming|3.7.0|The bug that lets engulfers pull engulfed monsters through iron bars that they could not pass otherwise is fixed via {{commit|21068b05c5c98ad7d5e50a9dbaa1b6256063e2e3}}. Per {{commit|f61e1e8e23f48f670c5b7c465089effd7743aba9}}, there is a small chance of breaking iron bars by hitting them with a [[war hammer]]. {{commit|c212ee44c06cb5ef5fec1a7f02d7c48c13f46fd6}} extends this to include hitting them with a [[heavy iron ball]]. The chance is dependent on the character's strength, whether they throw or force-fight with the weapon, and the weapon's enchantment or iron ball's weight. Per {{commit|738c2239c9063cbf62e5650977da45c1e38a3108}}, there is a {{frac|10}} chance that iron bars will melt when hit by [[lightning]]. Per {{commit|0e713dc4e90eba08ec50c4260a36161d5f3db4d8}}, all metallivores are also capable of eating iron bars. }} ==Strategy== Iron bars do not impede visibility, allowing spellcasting or wand-using players and monsters to direct their beams, rays and gazes through them. In particular, this can be used to pick off Orcish Town's invaders without as much immediate risk to yourself - but beware of the [[poison]]ed [[arrow]]s that many of them can fire back at you, especially if you lack [[poison resistance]]. The iron bars on the fourth variant of Medusa's Island present a significant hazard: you may inadvertently catch a glimpse of Medusa through the bars as you approach her, depending on where she is first generated, and risk being immediately [[petrified]]. Wearing a [[blindfold]] or [[towel]] well before approaching is a good idea, especially if you lack [[reflection]]. ==History== Iron bars first appear in [[NetHack 3.1.0]], when the [[Quest]] was introduced to the game. [[NetHack 3.6.0]] introduces the more commonplace iron bars in the main dungeon, and is the first version where certain monsters can eat through them; [[NetHack 3.6.1]] adds the ability to dissolve iron bars with acid, imported from UnNetHack. ==Variants== ===SLASH'EM=== In [[SLASH'EM]], iron bars can be found in some of the [[Sokoban (SLASH'EM)|Sokoban]] levels, and also appear in [[Grund's Stronghold]]. Some maze levels within the dungeon may be partially comprised of iron bars, e.g. in [[Gehennom]] - these can prove especially annoying during the [[ascension run]]. In addition to the applicable methods described above, player [[Doppelganger (starting race)|dopplegangers]] can use the [[liquid leap]] [[technique]] to pass through them. This can even be used on the iron bars in Sokoban, which otherwise prevents creatures from passing through them. ===SporkHack=== In [[SporkHack]], iron bars are sometimes generated as part of room-and-corridor dungeon levels. ===UnNetHack=== In [[UnNetHack]], iron bars appear in some of the [[Sokoban (UnNetHack)|Sokoban]] levels and Gehennom mazes as in SLASH'EM. They also appear much more frequently within the main dungeon, often replacing doorways and sections of rock wall within room-and-corridor levels - as mentioned above, UnNetHack is also the first variant that allows them to be dissolved via acid. A ring of iron bars is created around the [[magic portal]] connecting the [[Black Market]] to the main dungeon if you attempt to steal anything from the shops. ===dNetHack=== In [[dNetHack]], [[notdNetHack]] and [[notnotdNetHack]], characters can break iron bars with a [[wand of striking]], [[force bolt]], or a laser such as a [[lightsaber]] - this will produce 1-7 [[iron bar]] objects. These bars can be picked up and wielded as weapons, and use the [[quarterstaff]] skill. ===EvilHack=== In [[EvilHack]], iron bars can also be broken with a force bolt or wand of striking. ==References== {{nethack-367}} [[Category:Dungeon features]]
